title: 김지혜 박사 세미나 안내(9.24， 16：00­)
content:
김지혜 박사의 세미나를 다음과 같이 안내하오니 많은 참석을 부탁 드립니다.

ㅇ 일 시 : 9월 24일(수) 16:00-17:30
ㅇ 장 소 : 오상수 영상강의실(#4443)

Title: Robust Privacy-preserving Group Key Agreement Protocols

Abstract:

The last decade has witnessed a sharp spike in the popularity of group 
applications, such as video/audio conferencing, collaborative workspaces, as 
well as dynamic coalitions common in law enforcement and disaster rescue 
scenarios. Standard security services required in such group settings (such 
as confidentiality, integrity and authentication) can be efficiently 
achieved if all group members share a secret key. A group key agreement 
protocol (GKA) provide a technique for any set of participating players to 
collaboratively establish a shared key.

In this presentation, we tackle two challenging issues in GKA: robustness 
and privacy-preserving authentication. Robustness improves performance by 
guaranteeing completion of GKA protocols despite participating player or 
communication failures. Affiliation-hiding authenticated GKA (AH-AGKA) 
prevents from man-in-the-middle-attacks by authenticating players in a 
privacy-preserving manner.

We propose a two-round group key agreement protocol, which offers a natural 
trade-off between message size and the desired level of fault-tolerance. We 
demonstrate that in a realistic setting of random player faults, the new 
protocol has logarithmic-sized messages and expected round complexity close 
to two. We prove the security of the proposed protocols under the standard 
cryptographic assumptions.

We present the formal definition of the affiliation-hiding GKA in a standard 
PKI model with re-usable certificates. The model includes strong security 
properties, called perfect forward secrecy (PFS) and linkable 
affiliation-hiding (LAH) - that an key agreement protocol might provide in 
the face of player corruptions and session compromises. We construct two 
variants of optimal-cost AH-AGKA protocols, which satisfy PFS and LAH 
notions under the standard cryptographic assumptions in the random oracle 
model. The protocol yields minimal costs: three rounds of interaction 
matches the round complexity of non-private PFS authenticated GKA and its 
computation costs are comparable to the cost of unauthenticated GKA.
